##Sound diary: The weather is fine, today is my 8th day with new coronary pneumonia | story FM

Story

Features, welcome to the story FM. Here, we tell your story with your voice. Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, all platforms are updated simultaneously.

Click on the picture above to jump to the "story FM" applet and listen to the real person. Remember to add "my little program" , one-click to listen to the whole story Yo!

Today we're going to focus on the story of the epidemic.

As of February 7,2020,31,211 people across the country had been diagnosed with the disease. Today's narrator, wood, is one of those 30,000.

So is wood, a listener at story FM, who has recorded an audio diary on his phone every day since his diagnosis, recording his feelings of illness and isolation.

Today, we're going to play these sound diaries for you.

January 30th, the sixth day of the Lunar New Year, the first day of the quarantine

My name is wood, I am 31 years old, from Wuhan.

This Spring Festival, we are ready to take her parents-in-law, the wife's hometown of Chongqing a small county for the New Year.

On January 16, my father in law and his family met US in Wuhan, and on January 22, we drove back to Chongqing from Wuhan.

The day before we left, my father-in-law probably had a cold that night, a cold, and a cough in the car, but no other symptoms.

After returning to Chongqing, the city of Wuhan was sealed off. We knew the situation was getting a little serious. We started wearing masks when we went out to buy vegetables.

On the second and third day of the Lunar New Year, someone reported my Hubei a license plate, the community called to check, we also actively cooperate, revealed some personal information.

■ A car with the license plate of E A, and three alert cat images / visual China

My wife started to have a fever yesterday (January 29) . My father-in-law was coming to the hospital for a follow-up check, so we let him go first. If he is found to have a problem, then our whole family will be admitted for observation. If he is not found to have a problem, we're just GONNA keep it at home.

Shortly after 3:00 p.m. , the hospital told us that the CT results showed a lung infection, and that we should get it checked out as soon as possible.

Then my wife was diagnosed and admitted to the hospital on the spot. While my mother-in-law and I remained in quarantine.

This morning, I received a phone call from my daughter-in-law, she said that I suspect I have an infection, let me come as soon as possible.

To stop causing panic, I took a motorbike to the hospital myself. Hospital is divided into two floors, the first floor is the clinic, asked me some personal information, and then I came back from Wuhan after the movement of a table, I went to the isolation ward on the second floor.

Medical resources are stretched across the country, and I understand that, but it's also very worrying for me. When my father-in-law came to the hospital for his first checkup, there was a shadow on his lung, but this side said, "it's okay. "

If we could have done a throat swab at the time, we would have been able to confirm the diagnosis at the time, and maybe there wouldn't have been any follow-up.

Isolation Ward at County Hospital

The isolation here is also very unsafe, every ward has ventilation, patients can stand in the corridor smoking, chatting, door to door, no effect at all.

My Ward has three beds and a separate bathroom, but it's full of rust and looks very old. I've had blood drawn three times since I moved in, a throat swab, and no fluids.

At the county hospital

It is said that we will be transferred to a designated hospital at the city level tomorrow. The situation there is also not optimistic. Every day, patients from the district and county are sent there. The wards are also multi-occupancy. I don't know if there will be the possibility of cross-infection.

And I heard that after entering the cell phone, equivalent to the isolation of all external contact.

As soon as I heard the news, I paid off all my credit cards and the house loan that my wife and I were about to expire. I don't know if the new bills will be late when I get out, or if it will affect our credit report.

I haven't told my parents yet, but if I do, I'll have to.

I just wish my wife would get better. She's been through a lot.

I live with my mother-in-law now, and we're both asymptomatic, but it's confirmed.

She's being bombarded with phone calls and messages, and the small town is a society of acquaintances, and everyone knows we're quarantined. Everyone was on the phone, and she said it over and over and over again, telling them not to worry.

It was torture for her. It was like putting a knife in and pulling it out over and over again. It didn't stop the bleeding.

February 1, Day 3 of the quarantine, cloudy

It took us two and a half hours to get to the new hospital by ambulance after seven o'clock last night.

Ambulance for transfer

It's a miscommunication, but since we're in a room with seven people, it's hard to record at night.

Beds are also tight here, and some wards are even more crowded. When he arrived, he had a checkup, then 12 blood vessels were drawn, an aerosolized procedure, and a shot of thymosin.

The facilities and environment of the hospital have been upgraded and the medical staff are equipped with protective measures, but according to them, the medical supplies here are also very tight.

The paramedics are exhausted, they're in a hurry. The disease is so widespread that everyone has a different level of knowledge and understanding about it, and it's really hard for them not only to treat it, but also to deal with the irrational behavior of their patients.

The wooden ward

This hospital may be classified as a "new crown" virus treatment hospital soon, many facilities are not yet complete, there has been the sound of wall renovation, I can also understand. The food was delicious, with fruit and yogurt at every meal.

Both my wife and father-in-law are no longer feverish. But with the number of known patients in the outbreak, the cure rate is still low, and I don't know how much longer we can wait. My wife is relatively weak, so I'm worried about her.

I brought a professional book with me when I was in the hospital. Although I couldn't read it, I was able to pass the time.

Plus, this is where I had my first arterial bleed, which is a lot more painful than venous blood.

12 tubes of blood

February 2, Day 4 of the quarantine, light rain turns to overcast

I got up at 8:30 this morning and still heard a lot of decorating, but I slept okay.

■ meals provided by the hospital, each with fruit and yogurt

No tests, regular medication, anti-hiv meds.

Today's Food Has Green Pepper Fried Bacon, home-made Tofu and fungus fried meat, taste pretty good, but do not know is not the cause of medicine, I have no appetite.

I've been monitoring the progress of the outbreak for a few days, but after watching it for a long time, the most important thing is to get better quickly.

Discharge numbers are just numbers, behind are people like me, I only let myself get better quickly, let the number of recovery to increase in order to give confidence to patients.

We live in a closed area, there is a corridor can be a little activity, find a place where no one to breathe.

The corridor of the isolation ward

Most of the patients were checking video apps or calling family members to check in.

Some of the older brothers were in good spirits and took pains to call and talk to friends over and over again about what had happened to them. Their voices were so loud that they did not seem to have any illness at all.

I do not want to talk about it with others, but they are very optimistic, really admire.

If there's one thing I miss, it's freedom.

February 3rd, quarantine day five, cloudy to sunny

Today's routine remains the same: Medicine, temperature, atomization, injections, and a new CT SCAN, but the results are unknown.

People waiting to be examined

Being in isolation this long, it's bound to be anxiety, but I have faith in my body that I'm not going to be out of here forever.

But now the drug response is a bit big, appetite and diarrhea more obvious impact.

I know this outbreak has left a lot of people a little disappointed in society, but I think there are some positive things to think about.

You know, there are so many doctors and nurses... who have risked their lives for you... who can't be let down by anything.

I have classmates is medical workers, really like the News said that, after the closure of the city, from the hometown "retrograde" back to Wuhan, to join the first line of treatment.

These things happen right around you, and it's a big deal.

February 4th, quarantine day six, cloudy

After the infection, I have been in good health, there is no "new crown" pneumonia symptoms.

But some of my patients on this floor have had coughs and fevers, but they're all getting better.

The state of mind of this person is really quite good, some patients sing loudly outside every day, also bring a lot of joy.

This isolation has made me realize that I can actually adapt to my environment, even if it makes you feel uncomfortable or uncomfortable, but you have to adapt to it in order to survive.

If I leave the hospital and go back to Wuhan, I have to satisfy my appetite first.

I want to eat hot and dry noodles, crawfish, fried noodles, beef noodles, soup dumplings, bean skin, hot pot, barbecue..

I really wish this outbreak would go away.

■ Snack Street in Hubu Alley, Wuhan / Visual China

February 5th, the 7th day of the quarantine, rain

To the new hospital, I have been using anti-aids drugs, the Internet also said that this drug on the treatment of effective, but very risky.

Since I take this medicine, I go to bed at night will be all sweaty, breathing fast, not unobstructed nose.

My friends in Wuhan also had the infection, but their treatment was not quite the same as in Chongqing.

Personally, I prefer the body's ability to heal itself, and all treatment is to activate your ability to heal itself before you take medication.

I feel OK now, or no symptoms, just looked at the results of two days to do a nasopharyngeal swab.

■ A quiet hospital

February 6th, Quarantine Day eight, clear skies

I'd like to sum up what I've been feeling for so many days since I was diagnosed.

At first, my relatives were diagnosed. I was worried about the impact of SARS in 2003 on the lives of those infected.

My wife and I were supposed to have a baby this year, and this virus threw all our plans into disarray.

But when I was diagnosed, I wasn't so scared anymore. I usually keep on exercising myself, and I am still strong, mainly because I am worried about my family.

And then there's the issue of privacy. After we were diagnosed in the small town, not only we, but also a lot of home addresses, ID card numbers and portraits have been announced to the public.

I think it's Ok to publish some information, to do a good job of screening, but isn't it also an invasion of privacy to publish all the information?

My fellow patients and I are very optimistic.

A poverty-alleviation cadre has also moved in. Unbeknownst to him, he did a good deed and pulled a few passers-by, but one of them was from Hubei.

There are many people also do not know how infected, because of a variety of reasons to come in.

But no one was complaining, very positive. Things happen when they happen, and we deal with them as best we can.

Line 2, Wuhan Metro

I'd like to close with a quote from southern weekend that has inspired countless others:

At this moment,
We are Speechless (TV series) , but blessed:
Let the powerless be strong,
Let the pessimist go,
Let those who go on go on,
Make Happy People Happier;
And we're, like, rooting for you.

At this moment,

We are Speechless (TV series) , but blessed:

Let the powerless be strong,

Let the pessimist go,

Let those who go on go on,

Make Happy People Happier;

And we're, like, rooting for you.
